Award.AwardTitle: Development of an ultra-fast method for continuous and automated analysis of dissolved greenhouse gases in surface waters
Award.AbstractNarration:
Natural waters such as oceans, lakes, and rivers comprise the largest global reservoirs of numerous greenhouse gases in active exchange with the atmosphere. The diffusive fluxes of these gases between the dissolved aqueous phase and the atmosphere comprise significant fluxes regionally and globally. Previous techniques used to determine surface water concentrations and air-water fluxes primarily focus on collecting discrete samples of surface water in vials or the use of shower-head equilibrators. While collecting discrete samples provides accurate results, the relatively coarse sampling of the natural environment can lead to uncertainties in the true extent of surface water greenhouse gas concentration features. Shower-head equilibrators provide near-continuous data for higher resolution mapping, but the slow response time for gases of low solubility such as methane can render their results inaccurate during rapidly changing dissolved gas concentrations. Interestingly, the over the last few years, several studies have produced data suggesting that the flux of certain dissolved greenhouse gases are emitted to the atmosphere aggressively in extremely localized areas. However, the technology has not been available to quantitatively discover and map the full extent of these features.

This project will fully develop a new technique for the continuous analysis of dissolved greenhouse gas concentrations and natural isotopes in surface waters. The main advantage of this new system is an ultra-fast response time to changes in the surface water concentration of dissolved greenhouse gases while still maintaining high accuracy and precision analyses. More specifically, this technique will measure dissolved methane, carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, and nitrous oxide concentrations and natural stable isotopes. The principle of operation is vacuum gas extraction. Water is continually pumped through a gas-permeable membrane at a rate of 15 liters per minute and a vacuum is applied to the outside of the membrane to extract the dissolved gases from the water stream. The extracted gases are then pumped into an analytical detector for analysis. By comparing the water and extracted gas flow rates with the concentration of a specific greenhouse gas measured in the extracted gases, the dissolved gas concentration can be determined. The main weakness of this system is that the gas extraction efficiency is not 100%. Thus, an integrated and automated calibration system has been developed to quantify the dissolved gas extraction efficiency at predetermined intervals. A prototype of this system has been developed and preliminary tests have been conducted in the laboratory and northern Gulf of Mexico displaying results that are accurate, precise, and able to detect concentration changes on sub-minute timescales. This project will develop this technology to completion with the goal of fully validating the system for a suite of different greenhouse gases, physical and chemical water properties, and extraction membrane types. Laboratory tests and field trials will be conducted with the goal of engineering and validating a system that is user-friendly, portable, and fully automated for use within the scientific community. A graduate student from a group underrepresented in science will be involved in this project as will six undergraduate students. All of these student scientists will be given opportunities to contribute to the entire scientific process from data collection and interpretation to presentation and publication.

POR.DRECONTENT:
OVERVIEW:

The work conducted here developed an instrument for the fast, accurate, and automated analysis of dissolved greenhouse gas concentrations in surface waters.  Specifically, this work focused on carbon dioxide, methane, carbon monoxide, and the stable carbon isotopes of carbon dioxide and methane.  Prior to this project, two techniques were used to determine the concentration of different greenhouse gases dissolved surface waters.  One technique involved collecting and analyzing discrete water samples, a technique which produces high accuracy results but limits the ability to map spatial distributions.  The other technique involved a more continuous analysis while onboard an underway research vessel; while this technique can map spatial gradients, it can, at times, produce less accurate results.  The work conducted here solved these limitations by developing a vacuum gas extraction technique enabling the ability to not only map surface water distributions of these dissolved greenhouse gas concentrations, but to do so with a fast response time and high accuracy.  Briefly, while a research vessel is underway, surface water is continually pumped onboard through a gas permeable membrane and a vacuum is applied to the outside of the membrane.  The dissolved gases are vacuum extracted through the membrane and continually pumped into a laser spectrometer for continuous analysis.  A calibration routine was fully integrated into the design of this technique so that accurate results can be collected throughout a research expedition without a decrease in performance.  This technique was developed and validated in the laboratory and tested in the US Great Lakes of Lake Michigan and Lake Superior, as well as, the US Atlantic Margin.  In total, this project developed a fully automated instrument that can accurately measure dissolved concentrations of specific gases and do so with high spatial resolution, enabling both the discovery of small spatial scale features lastingly only a few meters and the mapping larger spatial gradients across oceanic regions.

 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT:

Oceanic and freshwater environments are large natural reservoirs of greenhouse gases in active exchange with the atmosphere.  Different processes in the overlying waters and underlying sediments can both form and destroy greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide; variations in the strengths of these processes can change a body of water from being a source to a sink of these gases from the atmosphere.  In order to measure the diffusive air-sea exchange of various gases, the concentration in the local atmosphere must be compared with the local concentration dissolved in surface waters.  However, oceanic and freshwater environments are not well mixed and significant spatial gradients are known to exist in the concentrations of various dissolved gas molecules.  In order to determine air-sea emission or uptake, the challenge is to accurately constrain the spatial distributions of greenhouse gases dissolved in surface waters.  The new technique developed here solves this challenge.

 

BROADER IMPACTS:

This work had both scientific and educational broader impacts.  Scientifically, this work developed an instrument which can be utilized by the scientific community to investigate local processes or to constrain regional to global-scale emissions of gases from the ocean to the atmosphere.  Educationally, this work supported three graduate students and helped them develop skills in instrumentation design and development, as well as skills in the presentation and publication of scientific results.  This project also gave numerous undergraduate students the opportunity to participate in the full scientific process within ocean sciences.  Prior to conducting experiments, a cohort of undergraduate students was mentored on how to (1) identify their research interests within the field of ocean biogeochemistry, (2) develop their interests into hypotheses, and (3) design an experimental plan to test their hypotheses.  These students were then given the opportunity to participate on the research expeditions associated with this project so that they could both enact their experimental plans while also contributing to the fundamental goals of this project.  These students found this experience empowering and many have since been accepted into highly competitive graduate school programs.
